The Welch Food, Inc. Process Safety Management / Risk Management Program has been developed and implemented and is continuously reviewed and updated for effectiveness. This program has organized the information and polices pertaining to the process into a complete library. 

Volume 1 of the PSM/RMP Library incorporates several policies. Many policies are included in Volume 1, the remaining are referenced from other training manuals maintained in the facility.

Employee Participation Guidelines: This policy outlines the commitment between management and employees to establish a program for a successful (safe) program.

Process Safety Information: This includes information on the ammonia inventory at the facility, applicable codes, design standards, and information pertaining to the hazards of ammonia (referenced from the IIAR ammonia Data Book).

Process Hazard Analysis Program: This program outlines a thorough, orderly, systematic approach for identifying, evaluating, and controlling potential hazards within a process involving potentially hazardous chemicals such as ammonia.

Operating Procedures: develop, implement, and maintain clearly written, detailed procedures, guidelines, rules, and practices for the safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration process during all operating phases. The operating procedures provide all employees involved in the operation and maintenance of the ammonia refrigeration process with the written information and precautions necessary to safety perform their tasks in a consistent manner.

Contractor Qualification Guidelines: This guideline has been established to verify that the contractors working in the facility are qualified to work on the system, trained in the hazards associated with their work, and made aware of the hazards presented by the facility to the employees of the contractor.

The Welch Food, Inc., is proud to inform all interested parties that our company is complying with OSHA's Process Safety Management Standard (PSM), Title 29 Code of Federal Regulations 1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Program regulations (RMP), Title 40 CFR Part 68. In addition to other state and local codes applicable to our facility and process. We have undertaken this process to deal with the risks involved with the storage, handling, and use of Anhydrous Ammonia in our facility.

Our goal is to promote overall worker, public, and plant safety. The Welch Food, Inc. facility is located at 139 South Lake Street, North East, PA. Welch's North East Plant is a manufacturing facility that receives grapes and packages juices, jellies, and jams.  The facility includes but is not limited to processing tanks, piping, raw materials warehousing, finished goods refrigerated storage, miscellaneous utilities, and three ammonia refrigeration systems that are located in three separate engine rooms (Tank Room 16, 72 Warehouse and Main System). Also, located at the facility is shipping and receiving docks. 

The facility has three separate ammonia systems.  The refrigeration systems exceed the 10,000-pound threshold required for our production process and necessitates the submission of this Risk Management Plan. 


ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
The Welch Food, Inc. is in the process of implementing numerous policies and procedures to enable our facility to prevent the occurrence and minimize the consequences of significant releases of Anhydrous Ammonia as well as other hazardous substances, fires, explosions, and other types of catastrophic accidents. Overall these programs prevent accidental fatalities, injuries, and illnesses and avoid property damage.  Our safety programs prevent accidents because they focus on the rules, procedures, and practices, which govern individual processes, activities, or pieces of equipment. These rules are co

grams have been developed to monitor and provide a checks and balances system to monitor changes in the facility and to verify that changes are safe and consistent with company policy.

Mechanical Integrity Program: To prevent or minimize the consequences of catastrophic releases of ammonia, it is important to ensure process equipment is maintained properly. The purpose of an MI program is to maintain process equipment so that a catastrophic release of ammonia is avoided or properly contained. The emphasis should be on preventive maintenance rather than breakdown maintenance.

Many more specific programs and policies (Hot Work, Confined Space, Lockout / Tagout, Employee training, etc.) have been developed. For information specific to these see the Operations Manager.

Process Hazard Analysis Re-validation was completed in 2018.  The PHA highlighted some deficiencies in the system. These items were addressed as part of the continuous improvement of the facility. These items were addressed on the basis of priority (Injuries to personnel). 

Procedures for conducting Compliance Audits, Mechanical Integrity Inspections, and Process Hazard Analyses are all part of our PSM/RMP Program.

Volume 2, 6, and 10 incorporates information on the specific system components (Pumps, vessels, compressors, evaporators, evaporative condensers, purgers, piping systems, heat exchangers, the emergency ventilation system, and general safety). This information is used as a reference source for the operator to positively identify system components. This manual also provides a checklist for performing the yearly Mechanical Integrity Inspection.
Volume 3, 7, and 11 incorporates a complete valve list for each system. The valve list contains information on the type, port size, identifying number, use, location, model, manufacturer, drawing reference, and normal operating position of each valve in the system.

Also included in Volume 3, 7, and 11 is the Process and Instrumentation

Diagrams for the individual system components. Flow schematics are included showing the entire systems. A block flow diagram provides a brief overview of the system. Drawings are included showing symbol and abbreviation descriptions. Plan views are included to allow the operator to physically locate equipment in the building.

Volume 4, 8 and 12 will incorporate a complete set of standard operating procedures, describing the proper steps for preparing components for start-up, starting components, monitoring normal operation of system components, shutting down components as part of normal operation, restarting equipment as part of normal operation, shutting down equipment for maintenance, restarting equipment after maintenance, shutting down equipment in emergency situations, restarting equipment after an emergency situations shutdown, and pumpout procedures. Also included as a part of each Standard Operating Procedure is the Technical Operating Specifications for the associated system component. This information includes consequences of deviation from standard operating procedures.

Volume 5, 9, and 13 contains Operation and Maintenance Information including manufacturer's information, spare parts list, maintenance procedures, and preventive maintenance procedures.

PROCESS DESCRIPTION
The Welch Food, Inc. North East, PA ammonia refrigeration systems are a standard compression and evaporation style systems. The Welch Food, Inc., is a food-based processing and distribution facility. 

WORST AND ALTERNATE CASE DESCRIPTION
The worst case scenario is of a vessel being ruptured by a forklift or other form of impact.  The alternate case scenario is a pipe rupture on the outlet of an ammonia pump, this could be caused by a forklift or other form of impact.

5 YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
The Welch Food, Inc. North East, PA facility has had no reportable releases in the last 5 years. There have been small nuisance odors that have resulted in incident investigations.

EMERGENCY ACTION PLAN
The Welch Food, Inc. has an Emergency Action Plan to establish procedures and guidelines to provide prompt and orderly action to emergencies involving the release of hazardous materials to prevent or minimize the potential health or environmental effects caused by such a release. The plan utilizes local emergency responders and contractors.

The Plan establishes lines of authority for conducting safe response operations, personnel roles and training, and communication procedures.  All employees are expected to comply with the plan in order to assure its effectiveness.

The plan provides guidelines for determining emergency recognition, proper levels of action, emergency communication, security and control. Guards are setup to monitor alarms from the Ammonia refrigeration system on a 24/7 basis, ensuring all ammonia related alarms, as well as operational upsets, are responded to immediately.


The Welch Emergency Action Plan involves the preparation of response plans detailed specifically to the Welch facility located in North East, Pennsylvania. True emergency response services are available in the community as detailed in the Welch Off-Site plan submitted and written by the Erie County Local Emergency Planning (LEPC) in conjunction with Welch emergency planners and is in compliance with the EPA Emergency Response Program requirements.

Welch's has a comprehensive emergency response Off-Site Plan that has been written by the Erie County Local Emergency Planning Commission (LEPC) in conjunction with Welch North East emergency planners. The Emergency Action Team is well equipped with chemical sensing equipment, personal protective equipment, and radio communication in order to determine the severity of the release.  This system includes provisions for interaction and support of off-site professional emergency responders.  If above acceptable limits set forth in the Emergency Action Plan, then local emergency response is called in to

handle the situation. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY
Welch Foods, Inc. is committed to continuous improvement of our policies, procedures, and facility. It is the intention of Welch Foods, Inc. to remain an industry leader. New technology, training techniques, and equipment are continuously being added to our system.
